rev.comment: /* China's Censoring */ removing old section, expanding new
rev.diff:
Line 183: Line 183:
====China's Censoring====
====China's Censoring====
â
The [[People's Republic of China]], whose [[human rights in the People's Republic of China|human rights record]] has been widely criticized by the international community, has in the past restricted citizen access to popular search engines such as [[Altavista]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[Google (search engine)|Google]]. The mirror search site [[Elgoog|elgooG]] has been used by Chinese citizens to get around blocked content. This complete ban is currently lifted. However, the government remains active in filtering Internet content.
+
The [[People's Republic of China]], whose [[human rights in the People's Republic of China|human rights record]] has been widely criticized by the international community, has in the past restricted citizen access to popular search engines such as [[Altavista]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[Google (search engine)|Google]]. The mirror search site [[Elgoog|elgooG]] has been used by Chinese citizens to get around blocked content. This complete ban is currently lifted. However, the government remains active in filtering Internet content. In October 2005, Blogger and access to the Google Cache were made available in China; however, in December 2005, some Chinese users of Blogger reported that their access to the site was once again restricted.
â
In the summer of 2005 Google's name became associated with commercial contracts between the Government of China, Microsoft and Cisco Systems which block access to websites using words like "democracy." Google has been involved with the removal of specific sites that are blocked in China from their Chinese news portal. The French news agency, AFP, reported that Microsoft, Yahoo! and Google have all agreed to cooperate in censoring the Internet from their China based sites by filtering out content objectionable to the Chinese government. The list of forbidden words includes "democracy," "freedom," "human rights," and "Taiwan independence."
+
In January 2006 Google affirmed its intent to filter certain keywords given to it by the Chinese government. The restrictions will apply to thousands of terms and websites.[http://www.breitbart.com/news/2006/01/24/D8FBCF686.html] The censored content will appear on a website called google.cn. Google was heavily criticized by the move, yet it claims it is necessary to keep the Chinese government from blocking Google entirely. The company does not plan to give the government information about the users that searches blocked content and will inform users of restricted categories. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4647398.stm] Google states on its Help pages that it does not censor content, but it does block pages demanded in certain jurisdictions, such as DMCA requests in the United States.
â   â
In October 2005, Blogger and access to the Google Cache were made available in China; however, in December 2005, some Chinese users of Blogger reported that their access to the site was once again restricted.
  â   â
In January 2006 Google affirmed its intent to censor material in China that the Chinese government found objectionable. The restrictions will apply to thousands of terms and websites.[http://www.breitbart.com/news/2006/01/24/D8FBCF686.html] The censored content will appear on a website called google.cn. Google was heavily criticized by the move, yet it claims itis doing the best it can to make more information accessible. The company does not plan to give the Chinese government information about the users that searches blocked content and will inform of restricted categories. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4647398.stm]
